page.title: 04Hampshire Cattle Breeders
page.content: This society was formed in 1944 by farmers in the New Forest Area who wished to prevent the transference of disease in cattle while mating. This is how Artificial Insemination first came into use. The society has a main centre in south Lyndhurst, they cover an area south to the Isle of Wight, north as far as the M4 and N.E. to Basingstoke. The society operates internationally, sending straws of semen to Canada, Germany and many other countries. Also members travel to these countries to buy cattle such as Holsteins from Canada, which are good for milk, and also Friesians although quarantine restrictions have been making cattle importing harder recently.
